comments: Zoom seminar

Synchronous seminar over zoom.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of modern European history and the various intellectuals that shaped that history.

This course gave me both a historical and theoretical background in the functions and practices of intellectuals over time. This course also introduced me to many major thinkers like Weber, Said, Gramsci, Sartre, and more. I

Most of the course is focused upon how European theorists and philosophers (mostly from the twentieth century) understood their own positionality and relationship to different types of power (economic, political, cultural, etc.). Lots of readings from within the Marxist/leftist intellectual tradition.

Learned so much about modern intellectual activity in Europe, and their relationship to political and social action. An incredible selection of readings with some, like Gramsci and Benjamin, that I haven't seen covered in another course at Yale. Really liked the political balance of the course as well, a good range of Marxist analysis and some more conservative critiques.
It was really interesting to study intellectuals themselves -- rather than to look at intellectuals just for reference into a particular time or idea.

I understood the development of various European intellectual traditions, as well as how intellectuals have viewed themselves. The class has given me clarity into how I should pursue my own future academic development.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Renaud is very thoughtful and kind. I thought Seminars were led very well too. No major critiques. I would highly recommend this class.

The strengths of this course were its varied and interesting syllabus and also Professor Renaud who helped us connect history, philosophy, sociology, and primary source documents. The course really lent itself to the discussion, and I enjoyed how we addressed both historical and contemporary moments.

There are many strengths to this course. Principally, the syllabus is excellent and covers a lot of interesting, seminal texts. Additionally, Professor Renaud is  very knowledgeable, accessible, and supportive, and the class discussions were consistently filled with astute comments from other students.

Prof. Renaud leads a really good discussion and really good insights are developed by everyone. Perhaps some weeks the reading was a bit too much, and we weren't able to get to it all, but all in all, I think the course was handled really well.

Strengths: Professor Renaud is really wonderful. He leads a discussion very well, he is really knowledgeable, and he really cares for his students. Professor Renaud was also really helpful at guiding and advising the final paper, giving students a lot of leeway to explore their own interests. The assigned readings were always interesting, and our long seminar never felt boring or lacking -- it often felt like we could have kept talking for another hour. 

Weaknesses: None specific to this course -- zoom learning is often a bit difficult, but there's nothing that Professor Renaud could have done about that.

Strengths: High-quality discussions, interesting readings

Improvements: There could be a selection of both liberal and conservative religious intellectuals on the syllabus

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked that we had a class reporter for almost every class. When you had to report, it forced you to really follow what was happening and if you missed what someone had said, you could always read the class reports. It would have been nice to have had the reports posted more quickly than they were but other than that, it was a very good system. Having people present in class also helped change the pace and keep things moving on zoom. It created some variation in the structure to each class.

The seminar was able to be conducted quite well over Zoom, and this was facilitated in part by student presentations, which I very much enjoyed. I think the seminar would have improved with a five-minute break in the middle of the class meeting; spending so much consecutive time over Zoom can be exhausting.
The course adapted pretty well to COVID -- no complaints!
The course worked well in the virtual environment. All elements of the course succeeded in their mechanical functions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. I had a very busy semester with some really difficult classes. This seminar was always a nice break from everything else. I enjoyed most of the readings and class discussions. If you're looking for a fun engaging class that won't stress you out too much, this is a good choice.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. Great professor, great readings. The class also manages to feel urgent and present in a way that not all humanities classes do.

Yes, I would recommend this course, because the readings are stimulating and the discussions are interesting. The topics forced me to grow as a thinker, and I was able to pursue a final project that I genuinely cared about.
I definitely would recommend it! Take it if you want to understand modern political currents from Marxism to neoliberalism.
Yes. You should definitely take this class. Renaud is a really great professor, and the material is really interesting.

Certainly. This course gave me important perspectives on the historical development of intellectuals, not only in Europe, but in other parts of the world as well. With this background, I can better understand the future of intellectuals and the academy.
